results.title: The 24 hour world
results.creator_credit: Terry Hughes, John Costello and London Television Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concorde”.
Portrays the world’s most interesting civil aircraft today - concorde - and includes some exciting shots of the aircraft in flight filmed with the R.A.F.’s Red Arrows. Sequences include: the development of civil aviation; evolution of Concorde; follow through of an actual test flight and coverage of Concord’s 1972 World Trip, via Iran, India, Singapore, Japan, to Australia

group_works.title: Would you kiss a naked man? (TEFC)
group_works.creator_credit: R. Alan Gough, Mary McLeod and Northern Century Productions

results.title: Would you kiss a naked man? (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: R. Alan Gough, Mary McLeod and Northern Century Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in sexuality”.
Demonstrates that sexuality and nudity are a natural part of an honest relationship between two people who care for one another by presenting a dramatized interlude between two teenagers in which they discuss the meaning of their relationship and engage in sexual play. From the series “Concepts in Sexuality”.

results.title: Electrochemistry
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontaria
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: chemistry”.
Shows students inside an everyday battery and explains the principles involved. Highlights the processes of electro-chemical reactions, how half-cell potentials can be determined, how electrochemistry is at work in the commercial Leclanche cell and the processes of corrosion and electrolysis. Each episode is ten minutes in duration: 1. The Building blocks of electrochemistry. 2. Electrochemical cells. 3. Designing electrochemical cells. 4. Commercial electrochemical cells. 5. Corrosion and 6. Electroplating.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontaria

results.title: The Mole concept
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: chemistry”.
The mole is the ultimate standard container for directly comparing large numbers of atoms and opens the way to understanding chemical reactions at the molecular level. Exercises in reasoning, using such theories as Gay-Lussac’s law of combining gas volumes and Avogadro’s hypothesis encourage class discussion. The six episodes are: 1. “Relative mass”, 2. “Gas volumes”, 3. “Combining gas volumes”, 4. “Avogadro’s hypothesis”, 5. “Relative atomic mass” and 6. “The Mole”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario

results.title: Organic chemistry 1
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and TV Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: chemistry”.
Starting with a look at the structure of carbon, the atom common to all living matter, these six 10 minute programs investigate the properties of carbon and its fascinating uses - in fuels, plastics, industry and domestic cleaning products. Computer animation illustrates bonding and reactions at the molecular level and simplifies complex concepts for greater understanding. The episodes are: 1. “Carbon the compromiser” 2. The shape of carbon” 3. “Fuels” 4. “Polyethylene” 5. “Industrial enzymes 6. Soaps and detergents

results.title: Secular soul. Part 2. Ceremonies [Widescreen]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Compass (Television program)”.
Presented by Geraldine Doogue, this three part series looks at the changing patterns of belief in Australia. Episode two examines the civil celebrant movement and the increase in rituals involving civil celebrants as opposed to traditional religious leaders. Doogue speaks to civil celebrant Dally Messenger, one of Australia’s longest practising civil celebrants, Diane Storey who specializes in funerals, John Hill, an ex Roman Catholic priest who missed the rituals of the church and became a civil celebrant, Gael Brigden, a celebrant on a television program, and Paul Charvet-Jackson who specialises in same sex commitment ceremonies. The celebrants share their thoughts on what inspires them, how they devise the rituals, the preparation that takes place, and the future of their profession. Features footage of weddings, a naming day and interviews with people who have enlisted the services of the celebrants. Part of the television show, “Compass”.
